abstractText: István Gyöngy It was during his time in high school that István first became fascinated about science. He was in a class, specialized in mathematics and physics, in the Trefort Ágoston Teacher Training School of Eötvös Loránd University, a famous high school in Budapest Hungary. Inspired by his outstanding mathematics teacher, dr. Gusztávné Reményi, and by exciting talks on solved and unsolved problems in mathematics, given by Pál Erdős for high school students in the Bolyai Mathematical Society, he decided to study mathematics at Eötvös Loránd University, where he was accepted immediately after high school. At the university, Istvánwas influenced by the excellent lectures of Pál Turán in number theory, András Hajnal in mathematical logic, and by the tutorials of Róbert Freud in algebra and number theory, and became enthusiastic about these subjects. It was at Eötvös LorándUniversity that Istvánmet his good friend János Pintz who has since become a famous number theorist. After graduating from the university with distinction, he first got a lecturer position at the Technical University of Budapest, followed by the Department of Algebra and Number Theory of Eötvös LorándUniversity. Just before leaving his first employment, he received a grant to spend two months in the Banach Center in Warsaw. During his visit to the Banach Center, a program on martingale theory and its applications was organized by Zbigniew Ciesielski and Jerzy Zabczyk, and mathematicians from various parts of the world were invited to give series of lectures. These lectures, in particular the lectures on controlled diffusion processes by Nicolai Krylov, profoundly changed István’s mathematical interests, and led him to apply for PhD studies under Krylov’s supervision at Moscow State University. He was accepted and started his PhD studies there in 1978. István Gyöngy It was during his time in high school that István first became fascinated about science. He was in a class, specialized in mathematics and physics, in the Trefort Ágoston Teacher Training School of Eötvös Loránd University, a famous high school in Budapest Hungary. Inspired by his outstanding mathematics teacher, dr. Gusztávné Reményi, and by exciting talks on solved and unsolved problems in mathematics, given by Pál Erdős for high school students in the Bolyai Mathematical Society, he decided to study mathematics at Eötvös Loránd University, where he was accepted immediately after high school. At the university, Istvánwas influenced by the excellent lectures of Pál Turán in number theory, András Hajnal in mathematical logic, and by the tutorials of Róbert Freud in algebra and number theory, and became enthusiastic about these subjects. It was at Eötvös LorándUniversity that Istvánmet his good friend János Pintz who has since become a famous number theorist.
After graduating from the university with distinction, he first got a lecturer position at the Technical University of Budapest, followed by the Department of Algebra and Number Theory of Eötvös LorándUniversity. Just before leaving his first employment, he received a grant to spend two months in the Banach Center in Warsaw. During his visit to the Banach Center, a program on martingale theory and its applications was organized by Zbigniew Ciesielski and Jerzy Zabczyk, and mathematicians from various parts of the world were invited to give series of lectures. These lectures, in particular the lectures on controlled diffusion processes by Nicolai Krylov, profoundly changed István’s mathematical interests, and led him to apply for PhD studies under Krylov’s supervision at Moscow State University. He was accepted and started his PhD studies there in 1978. During the seventies and eighties of the last century, the theory of stochastic processes, stochastic calculus, stochastic differential equations and stochastic partial differential equations (SPDEs) were being rapidly developed in several mathematical centers of the world, among them in Moscow. hugely benefit from seminars organized by Krylov and Shiryaev. His PhD dissertation on “Stochastic evolution equations" developed further the Pardoux-Krylov-Rozovskii theory of SPDEs. He defended it in front of a committee chaired by A. N. Kolmogorov in 1981.
After his PhD studies he continued working in the Department of Algebra and Number Theory, and then in the Department of Probability and Statistics at Eötvös Loránd University.
His mathematical development was helped greatly by the Humboldt Fellowship in the Goethe University Frankfurt (1984-85), the Keldysh Fellowship in the Steklov Mathematical Institute Moscow (1987-88), by the invited professorship at the University of Provence (Marseilles 1991-92), the visiting professorship at the University of Barcelona (1993-95), and by visiting positions at Carlton University Ottawa, at ETH Zürich, at the University of Minnesota, the University of Melbourne, the University of Paris X, the University of Paris I and at the École Normale Supériore de Rennes.
Since 1995 he works in the School of Mathematics at the University of Edinburgh, teaching various courses in mathematics and mathematical finance.
Professor I. Gyöngy is a very active researcher in Probability Theory and its Applications. According to the MathSciNet his publications are cited 1585 times by 887 authors (as of June 2021). He was an invited speaker at more than sixty workshops/conferences. Not surprisingly this attracted to him talented students and he supervised ten PhD dissertations. Out of about 90 of his papers more than half are joint papers with many co-authors some with his students. In particular, this shows how valuable and desirable collaborator and supervisor he is.
In 2005 he was elected as a member of the Royal Society of Edinburgh (Scottish Academy of Sciences).
He considers himself extremely lucky that he has had and has many great teachers, friends and colleagues and constant support of his fantastic family, wife Anna, and their children Istvan, Miklós, Anna and Thomas.
